author: VNExplorer
title: Este es Pedro: el oso perezoso m√°s guapo de todo el reino animal
text:
Este animal vive en Costa Rica y es una invitaci√≥n para que las personas donen para la conservaci√≥n de su especie y h√°bitat.
Ha conquistado el coraz√≥n de los usuarios en internet.
Pedro ha conquistado los corazones de los usuarios de las redes sociales. Este es conocido como el oso perezoso m√°s guapo del reino animal, seg√∫n la Fundaci√≥n Internacional para la Conservaci√≥n del Perezoso, que le ha otorgado dicho t√≠tulo.
El animal habita en las selvas de Costa Rica y es el personaje del a√±o para la organizaci√≥n, que lo ha exhibido en videos para mostrar lo cautivador que es este perezoso.
Por ello, el ejemplar, que parece modelo de portada de revista, ya suma m√°s de 12 millones de reproducciones en las redes sociales.
No obstante, su personalidad tambi√©n ha sido un factor que llama la atenci√≥n, pues se ha desenvuelto con facilidad frente a las c√°maras.
El motivo, por el que la organizaci√≥n visibiliza a Pedro, no solo se debe a que tiene un pelaje definido y una expresi√≥n tierna.
As√≠, buscan incentivar que las personas se postulen para ser padres adoptivos, que donen para la preservaci√≥n de su especie y su h√°bitat natural.
Los perezosos habitan en las selvas tropicales de Am√©rica Central y del Sur en pa√≠ses como Panam√°, Costa Rica, Colombia, Brasil, Surinam y Venezuela. Existen seis especies de este animal, de ellas: tres est√°n en nivel de menor preocupaci√≥n seg√∫n la Lista Roja de Especies Amenazadas de la Uni√≥n Internacional para la Conservaci√≥n de la Naturaleza (Uicn); uno est√° en peligro cr√≠tico de extinci√≥n; y las otras dos especies est√°n consideradas como vulnerables.
üêæ ¬øQuiere estar al d√≠a y conocer las √∫ltimas noticias sobre el mundo animal? Lo invitamos a verlas en La Red Zoocial. üê∂üê± Adem√°s, si tiene alguna historia o est√° interesado en contar la suya con su mascota, puede escribirnos a [email protected]

author: UK News
title: Protest at Catholic girls school a sign of ‚Äòdeeper malaise‚Äô in Northern Ireland
text: Protest at Catholic girls school a sign of ‚Äòdeeper malaise‚Äô in Northern Ireland A meeting David Trimble had with residents was said to be ‚Äòinstrumental in creating the climate for a discontinuation of the protest‚Äô. A loyalist protest at a Catholic girls school in north Belfast in 2001 was a sign of a ‚Äúdeeper malaise‚Äù in Northern Ireland according to Bertie Ahern, new archives show. Officials who compiled documentation of efforts to resolve the protest also noted criticisms of DUP MP for Belfast North Nigel Dodds for his actions, and said that then First Minister David Trimble‚Äôs efforts were integral. For months in 2001, locals at Holy Cross primary school in north Belfast stood outside the school as girls and parents walked in The protest began following a clash in June 2001 as a man collected his child. ‚ÄúHe was, according to nationalists, attacked by loyalists when he objected to them putting up paramilitary flags on the Ardoyne Road,‚Äù a briefing note stated. Efforts to resolve the issue over the summer break failed, and the protests resumed in the autumn. Loyalists said they were protesting because of attacks on their community, which they claimed were prompted by the larger Catholic population and wanted better security in the Ardoyne area as a result. The note from November said: ‚ÄúThe hate-filled aggression the loyalist protesters showed to the primary school girls and their families has disturbed, dismayed, and angered people throughout Northern Ireland and in the wider world beyond.‚Äù On October 18 2001, Fr Aidan Troy had an hour-long meeting with Mr Ahern in which he discussed the impasse over the protest, which had been ongoing for months. Fr Troy, parish priest of Ardoyne and chair of the board of governors of the Holy Cross school, said that there were around 20 people on both sides of the road in the morning, and 60-70 people on each side in the afternoon. ‚ÄúA hard core‚Äù of local residents took part in the protests and there was also a ‚Äúsinister‚Äù loyalist paramilitary involvement, as well as people from other loyalist areas taking part, according to notes taken of the meeting. Fr Troy said that some residents from Glenbryn, the protestant and loyalist area around the school, expressed support for his work, usually anonymously because of the ‚Äúclimate of fear‚Äù surrounding those who opposed the protest. He said that some children and parents had been subjected to abuse including ‚Äúballoons filled with dog excrement and urine, scalding water, stones and a blast-bomb‚Äù. A blast bomb attack had taken place the day before the meeting on Alliance Avenue. Of the 220 pupils at the school, 35 were stressed and receiving counselling and medication, and 10 had been transferred to other schools. The priest expressed concern that the protest could ‚Äúdrag on indefinitely‚Äù, as it was a no-cost effort from protesters, and said this could put an ‚Äúintolerable strain‚Äù on the school community. He also said that there was ‚Äúa leadership vacuum‚Äù in Glenbryn, which was an impediment to progress, and the referral to a committee of 14 people with ‚Äúno common agenda‚Äù made it difficult to find a resolution. Fr Troy also said that while he appreciated the work of police to protect children on the way to school, he was ‚Äúunhappy‚Äù that protesters were allowed to be so close that they were able to ‚Äúspit at the children‚Äù and was confused as to why armed soldiers faced towards the parents and children. Mr Ahern said that the root causes of the protests were a ‚Äúsymptom of a deeper malaise within Northern Ireland‚Äù. He offered to raise the issue during a meeting with the UK Prime Minister Tony Blair the next day, but said that genuine progress could only be achieved through engagement and agreement at local level. Fergal Mythen, an Irish official in the Security Section of the Department of Foreign Affairs, compiled the notes of the meeting on October 22 2001. In notes taken by the British Irish Intergovernmental Secretariat, dated November 21, it said Fr Troy was ‚Äúreasonably confident‚Äù of an end or suspension to the protest ahead of a meeting with Mr Trimble and deputy first minister Mark Durkan. Mr Dodds, who was to chair a meeting of residents at Stormont, was noted as a sign of a possible deal, as ‚ÄúDodds has sat on the loyalist fence on may issues and is not known to stick his neck out unduly‚Äù. In a briefing dated November 26, it called Mr Trimble and Mr Durkan‚Äôs meeting with Glenbryn residents the previous week, as well as a prompt follow-up letter ‚Äúinstrumental in creating the climate for a discontinuation of the protest‚Äù. The material can be viewed in the National Archives in file 2023/53/67.

author: Evan Thomason
title: Snowpack is lacking with no major additions of snowfall - Local News 8
text:
IDAHO (KIFI) - Lackluster snowfall is starting off the winter season across Idaho. A few areas near the Magic Valley and Pocatello are close to their seasonal averages of snowfall for this time of year, but east and central Idaho aren't faring as well.
Most of the Snake River Plain, central ID, and far eastern ID have snowpack that is well below their seasonal average for this time of year. A few snow systems rolled through these areas, but haven't dumped a considerable amount of snowfall at. Areas including the Salmon Basin to the Big Lost and Little Lost Basins, all the way over to the Upper Snake River Plain, have a snowpack around 60 to 70% of their usual snowpack at this time of year.
The southern highlands and southeast Idaho are doing better, but are trending in a worse direction. They hold snowpacks that are just above their seasonal averages, around 110%, but most of that is from a good amount of early winter snowfall. They held 130 to 150% of their seasonal snowpack just a week or two ago.
Temperatures are warmer than average, and rain showers haven't helped either. Both have been present across the region well into December, especially in the valleys.
The long-term winter outlook isn't trending for the better. It shows the region having slightly below average precipitation for the rest of the winter.
The only positive outlook, according to water expert, is that we are carrying over a lot of water storage into 2024. This is usually the time of the year where reservoirs are at their lowest, yet most reservoirs still have at least half of their full capacity.

author: BP Editor 7
title: Dr Annuar hails Sibu‚Äôs Kg Nangka as shining example of racial, religious unity
text: SIBU (Dec 29): Kampung Nangka here, where many villagers of different faiths live under one roof, has been hailed as a shining example of racial unity and religious harmony. In saying this, Education, Innovation and Talent Development Deputy Minister Datuk Dr Annuar Rapaee opined if there is an award for the most united village in Malaysia, the accolade should go to Kampung Nangka. ‚ÄúI have visited many houses in Kampung Nangka, where in one house, the families can be of different religious beliefs. ‚ÄúThe mother could be celebrating Christmas, while the daughter, celebrates Hari Raya Aidilfitri. Or, the elder brother is celebrating Christmas, the younger brother celebrates Hari Raya Aidilfitri. ‚ÄúThere is no issue amongst these families, where they live happily and harmoniously under one roof. This clearly shows that despite our differences in religions, we can still live together harmoniously ‚Äì this is not impossible,‚Äù the Nangka assemblyman said at the village‚Äôs Christmas party at its futsal court last night. The event was organised by the Kampung Nangka village security and development committee (JKKK). Elaborating further, Dr Annuar stressed that respecting each other‚Äôs religious beliefs is key to religious harmony. ‚ÄúYou as Christian, respect me as a Muslim, and likewise, as a Muslim, I respect those of Christian faith. If there is this principle of respecting each other‚Äôs religion then, this world will be a more peaceful place to live in,‚Äù he said. He was sad to note there were certain quarters playing the religion card for political mileage or to cause division among the people. Dr Annuar said he is keen to bring others to visit houses in Kampung Nangka to see how interfaith families live harmoniously together under one roof. He urged Kampung Nangka folk to continue preserving and safeguarding this racial unity and religious harmony. He also advised villagers to approach community leaders or himself should they face any problems. ‚ÄúI admit I can‚Äôt solve everything, but will do my level best to lessen their burden,‚Äù he added. Among those present at the event were Persatuan Kebajikan Melanau Kampung Nangka Sibu (PKMKNS) advisor Maria Dris as well as PKMKNS chairman and Sibu Municipal Council (SMC) councillor Abang Carrol Abang Dris.

author: LUCA POWELL Richmond Times-Dispatch
title: Virginia mail delivery is 4th worst in nation
text: Richmond‚Äôs new Sandston post office is moving up the ladder, albeit slowly. Once the worst in the nation for delivering First-Class Mail, the Virginia postal region is now only fourth-worst. That‚Äôs according to performance data updated this week by a watchdog agency that monitors the U.S. Postal Service . The numbers suggest that Richmond's mail service is rebounding, even while other postal regions across the U.S. experience their own performance declines. People are also reading‚Ä¶ In the first few months of 2024, the Postal Service in Virginia had a 66% on-time delivery rate for First-Class Mail, indicating the percentage of that category of mail delivered within a two-day window. In the spring, that score increased to 77%. This week‚Äôs data charts Virginia's rating at 78%. That‚Äôs the score for two-day delivery of First-Class Mail sent through Virginia between April and June of this year. The Postal Service is in the throes of a nationwide transformation. The agency is a year into its plan to make the agency financially solvent, an initiative spearheaded by Postmaster Louis DeJoy, a Trump-era appointee. The plan focuses on consolidating the agency‚Äôs network of post offices, as well as refocusing on package delivery. The makeover was initially calculated to save USPS‚Äô Virginia operations $186 million over 10 years. Virginia was the first postal region in the country to be revamped under the plan. Shortly after, the region‚Äôs on-time delivery rate dropped from 85% to the 66% figure. The tracking numbers come from the Office of the Inspector General for the Postal Service, one of two watchdog agencies that monitors the Postal Service. 'Virginians deserve far better' Virginia lawmakers have previously said the marginal improvements will not suffice . ‚ÄúVirginians deserve far, far better than the fourth-worst mail delivery in the nation," said Rep. Abigail Spanberger, D-7th. "I continue to hear from Virginians who are experiencing unacceptable mail service and delivery issues, such as bills arriving past-due, packages getting stuck in an endless loop of trips in and out of the Richmond RPDC, and checks getting lost in the mail." Spanberger said mail delivery continues to be "indefensible." The agency has set a target goal of 93% on-time delivery for First-Class Mail. ‚ÄúIt should be in the low 90s,‚Äù Rep. Jennifer McClellan, D-4th, told the Richmond Times-Dispatch in May. McClellan likened the marginal improvements to going from an ‚ÄúF‚Äù to an ‚ÄúF-plus.‚Äù Rep. Rob Wittman, R-1st, echoed that sentiment. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy that they‚Äôre making progress, but they‚Äôre not where they need to be,‚Äù Wittman said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre giving us lots of metrics, but the metric that matters is what customers see.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve asked them to hold a town hall and, at first they said no, but now they‚Äôre talking like they‚Äôre going to do it,‚Äù he added. Sen. Tim Kaine said that when he and others from the congressional delegation sat down with Postmaster General DeJoy in early July, ‚ÄúHe said: I apologize, we really screwed up.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe're not near where we want to be, but we can see the gap closing,‚Äù Kaine said. ‚ÄúOne other thing I've been noticing is because people call our office with complaints, I can track, oh, how many people complain about the post office this month, last month, month before. We're seeing the number of complaints dramatically down, although they are staying high in and around Charlottesville.‚Äù 'Transformational change is critical' The Postal Service has repeatedly declined to make Richmond postal managers or administrators available for interviews to talk about the transition occurring in Sandston. In April, however, an audit from the same inspector general‚Äôs office dove into detail on problems occurring at the Sandston facility. The auditors found operational failures and millions in unexpected costs . In response to questions on the Postal Service‚Äôs performance standards in Virginia, a spokesperson for the agency directed The Times-Dispatch to comments made in response to that audit , which were fielded on March 22 of this year. In those comments, a group of USPS vice presidents wrote that Sandston‚Äôs growing pains were temporary but necessary, given that business as usual prior to the Delivering for America plan ‚Äúpersistently failed to meet our service performance targets.‚Äù ‚ÄúTransformational change is critical, it is also never easy, even when it is for the better, particularly when considering an organization that is the size of the Postal Service, and whose current network and operating practices are so misaligned,‚Äù wrote USPS executives Dane Coleman, Robert Cintron, Steve Dearing, Elvin Mercado and Todd Hawkins. Both auditors and the executives agreed on the wisdom of using the avoidable mistakes made in Richmond as a template for future states, many of which will or are currently undergoing similar overhauls. That includes states like Georgia, Wisconsin and Texas. The Atlanta mail region was overhauled according to the Delivering for America plan shortly after Richmond. Atlanta is currently worst in the country for on-time delivery of First-Class Mail, with a 40% score. The on-time delivery rate nationwide also dropped within the same most recent period. During this same period last year, USPS‚Äô nationwide score for First-Class Mail was 91.8%. This year, the average stands at 85.6%, a 6.2% decrease. A national issue Many legislators have viewed those low scores as a mark of little confidence in Postmaster DeJoy. In June, Spanberger wrote a letter to President Joe Biden requesting he fill a final vacancy on the USPS Board of Governors, which has the authority to appoint or remove the USPS Postmaster. "Under the tenure of the current Postmaster General, the American people have seen our most beloved federal agency grossly mismanaged, undermined, and nearly destroyed. Virginians have suffered some of the worst consequences of Postmaster General DeJoy‚Äôs detrimental policy changes in the past year,‚Äù Spanberger wrote. Steve Hutkins, a retired New York University professor who now chronicles USPS issues on his ‚ÄúSave the Post Office‚Äù website, previously told The Times-Dispatch that spotty, unreliable mail delivery has become a national issue as DeJoy rolls out big changes. ‚ÄúThings are just not working as planned. They‚Äôre making big changes faster than the network can keep up with it, and it‚Äôs not even clear how long this will go on and what the outcome will be when it‚Äôs all over,‚Äù Hutkins told The Times-Dispatch in March. Luca Powell (804) 649-6103 @luca_a_powell on Twitter

26/09/2024 ‚Ä¢ 19:54 ‚Ä¢ Atualizado em 26/09/2024 ‚Ä¢ 19:54 Um dia depois de Israel frustrar o ataque a m√≠ssil feito pelo Hezbollah, o grupo xiita usou as redes sociais para exibir o pr√≥prio potencial b√©lico. O v√≠deo mostra o disparo de diversos m√≠sseis e traz apenas uma frase: ‚ÄúFoi deus quem lan√ßou‚Äù.
Na √∫ltima quarta-feira (25), mais de 50 pessoas morreram nos bombardeios israelenses contra o L√≠bano. Entre eles, o adolescente brasileiro Ali Kamal Abdallah, de 15 anos, e o pai dele, liban√™s de nacionalidade paraguaia.
Nesta quinta-feira (26), a morte de outra jovem brasileira foi confirmada, a de Mirna Raef Nasser, de 16 anos, natural de Balne√°rio Cambori√∫. O pai dela, liban√™s, tamb√©m morreu. O ex√©rcito de Israel diz que os alvos eram redutos do Hezbollah, na periferia de Beirute.
‚ÄúN√£o tem casa. N√£o sobrou nada. Eles atacaram casa de civil. Eles falam para o jornal que atacaram a base de militar. N√£o tem nada daquilo que eles falam. Atacaram s√≥ casa de gente pobre, trabalhador‚Äù, lamentou o tio de Mirna.
Bombardeios de Israel atingiram o sul do L√≠bano pelo quarto dia seguido. Os ataques j√° mataram mais de 600 pessoas e deixaram cerca de 3 mil feridas.
O primeiro-ministro de Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, descartou o cessar-fogo proposto por Estados Unidos e Fran√ßa. O plano previa a interrup√ß√£o dos bombardeios por tr√™s semanas.
Ao desembarcar em Nova York, onde discursar√° na Assembleia Geral da ONU, Netanyahu reiterou que os ataques continuar√£o com for√ßa total.
Nas Na√ß√µes Unidas, o presidente da Autoridade Palestina disse que o mundo inteiro √© respons√°vel pelo genoc√≠dio na regi√£o. Mahmoud Abbas pediu san√ß√µes internacionais a Israel e o fim do que chamou de "loucura" sobre o que acontece em Gaza e na Cisjord√¢nia.
